revisions.rev:
{{Infobox Football club | clubname = Paris Saint-Germain | current = 2010â11 Paris Saint-Germain F.C. (Ladies) season | image = | founded = 1991 (FÃ©minines) | nickname = PSG Ladies, Les Parisiennes | ground = Stade Georges LefÃ¨vre, [[Paris]] | capacity = 3,500 | chairman = Pierre NoguÃ¨s | manager = Camillo Vaz | league = [[Division 1 FÃ©minine]] | season = [[2010â11 Division 1 FÃ©minine|2010â11]] | position = [[Division 1 FÃ©minine|D1]], [[2010â11_Division_1_FÃ©minine#League_table|2nd]] | website = http://www.psg.fr/ | pattern_la1 = _psg1112h | pattern_b1 = _psg1112h | pattern_ra1 = _psg1112h | pattern_so1 = _psg1112h | leftarm1 = 000040 | body1 = 000040 | rightarm1 = 000040 | shorts1 = 000040 | socks1 = 000040 | pattern_la2 = _psg1112a | pattern_b2 = _psg1112a | pattern_ra2 = _psg1112a | pattern_so2 = _psg1112a | leftarm2 = FFFFFF | body2 = FFFFFF | rightarm2 = FFFFFF | shorts2 = FFFFFF | socks2 = FFFFFF }} '''Paris Saint-Germain Football Club''', also known simply as '''Paris Saint-Germain''' and familiarly as '''PSG Ladies''' is a professional women's [[football (soccer)|football]] club based in [[Paris]], [[France]]. The club has been the female section of [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]] since 1991. Paris Saint-Germain Ladies is managed by Camillo Vaz - in his third season since replacing Ãric Leroy. The club is chaired by Pierre NoguÃ¨s. The Stade Georges LefÃ¨vre of the [[Camp des Loges]] in [[Saint-Germain-en-Laye]], with a capacity of 3,500 seats, is the main stadium of the club. The [[2010â11 Paris Saint-Germain F.C. (Ladies) season|2010â11]] season became their 12th season in [[Division 1 FÃ©minine]] and their 10th consecutive season in the top-flight of [[Football in France|French football]]. Paris Saint-Germain won the [[:fr:Championnat de France de football fÃ©minin D2|Division 2 FÃ©minine]] in 2001 and were promoted to the top-tier. Since then Paris Saint-Germain has never been relegated from the Division 1 FÃ©minine. Paris Saint-Germain captured their first major title and most prestigious honour to date by defeating [[Montpellier HSC (Ladies)|Montpellier]] in the [[2010 Challenge de France Final|Coupe de France FÃ©minine Final]]. The ladies were runner-ups of the cup in [[:fr:Challenge de France fÃ©minin 2007-2008|2008]]. Paris Saint-Germain finished runners-up in Division 1 FÃ©minine and qualified to the [[UEFA Women's Champions League]] for the first time in their history in [[2010â11 Division 1 FÃ©minine|2011]].{{cite news | title = PrÃ©sentation (fÃ©minines) | url = http://www.psg.fr/fr/Feminines/409001/Presentation-feminines | work = PSG.fr | accessdate = 30 September 2010}} ==History== [[File:PSG fÃ©minines CFF 2010.jpg|thumb|220px|right|"Les Parisiennes" lift the [[2009â10 Challenge de France|French Cup]] title.]] The first record of a Paris Saint-Germain female side can be traced back to 1971. The club had licensed a few women before the 1971â72 season but there wasn't a women's football section or even a team.''Paris St-Germain'', NÂ°1 de septembre 1971, p.13 33 women were licensed by the club and a senior female team was registered in the [[:fr:Ligue de Paris Ãle-de-France de football|Division d'Honneur de Paris]] in 1972.''Paris Football Club'', NÂ°8 de juin 1972, p.9 The [[Camp des Loges]] hosted the so-called Â« big match to promote women's football Â» on 21 January 1979. It was contested by the [[Stade de Reims]] Ladies, 1978 Women's World Invitation Tournament champions in [[Taiwan]], and a team composed of Parisian players.{{cite news | title = Women's World Invitation Tournament 1978 | url = http://www.rsssf.com/tablesw/wom-wit78.html | work = [[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]] | date = 31 December 2009 | accessdate = 17 October 2011}} PSG played in the DH Paris until 1980, when they were promoted to the [[Division 1 FÃ©minine]], re-instated by the [[French Football Federation]] in 1975, after its allotment of clubs was increased from 20 to 48. Paris Saint-Germain were vice-champions of the Division 1 FÃ©minine in 1983 and 1985.{{cite news | title = France - List of Women Final Tables | url = http://www.rsssf.com/tablesf/fran-womhist.html | work = [[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]] | date = 12 August 2009 | accessdate = 17 October 2011}} PSG Ladies, as the official female section of [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]], was founded in 1991. Therefore, the club does not recognize the history, titles and statistics before 1991. Casually, that same year the French Football Federation decided to change the competition format of the Division 1 FÃ©minine for the following season. Since 1974, the league consisted of several groups with the winners of each group entering a playoff phase to determine the champion. The 1991â92 season was the last one with that format. A new rule was created, however, to make way for the new competition format being set up for the 1992â93 season and onwards. The Division 1 had 30 clubs spread in three groups with 10 clubs each. The new format, however, consisted of 12 clubs in a single group. In order to eliminate the remaining 18 clubs, the four highest placed teams from each group would stay in the Division 1 FÃ©minine while the six lowest placed teams from each group would be relegated to the [[:fr:Championnat de France de football fÃ©minin D2|Division 2 FÃ©minine]]. The newly formed PSG Ladies suddenly found themselves in Division 2 after finishing fifth just one point behind the fourth spot, synonymous with top-flight status for the 1992â93 season. [[File:Victoire PSG fÃ©minines Montpellier.jpg|thumb|220px|left|The ladies celebrate their qualification to the [[UEFA Women's Champions League]].]] PSG Ladies achieved promotion to the Division 1 in 1994 after two seasons in the second tier.{{cite news | title = France - List of Women Second Level (N1B) Final Tables | url = http://www.rsssf.com/tablesf/fran-wom2hist.html | work = [[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]] | date = 25 May 2001 | accessdate = 17 October 2011}} Their return was short-lived, however, and following a disastrous 1994-95 season, "Les Parisiennes" were relegated back to Division 2. PSG garnered only 6 points after recording 2 victories, 2 draws and 18 defeats. Six years later, Paris Saint-Germain won the Division 2, the club's first trophy, and were promoted to the top-flight in 2001. Since then Paris has never been relegated from the Division 1. PSG continued without major problems among the elite but never within the top clubs under coach Cyril Combettes. The best players in the club at the time were [[BÃ©rangÃ¨re Sapowicz]], [[Laure Boulleau]], [[:fr:Nonna Debonne|Nonna Debonne]] and [[Sabrina Delannoy]]. Cyril Combettes resigned due to relationship problems with the players and was replaced by Ãric Leroy in 2007. He guided PSG to the [[:fr:Challenge de France fÃ©minin 2007-2008|French Cup Final]] against [[Olympique Lyonnais (ladies)|Olympique Lyonnais]] at the [[Stade de France]] in 2008. PSG conceded three goals after having withstood the French champion in the first half.{{cite news | title = Finale au stade de France : PSG - OL | url = http://www.footofeminin.fr/Finale-au-stade-de-France-PSG-OL_a168.html | work = Footofeminin.fr | date = 2 June 2008 | accessdate = 3 May 2010}} After a disappointing [[2008â09 Paris Saint-Germain F.C. (Ladies) season|2008-09]] campaign, Ãric Leroy handed over the job to Camillo Vaz in 2009. PSG signed French internationals [[Ãlise Bussaglia]], [[:fr:Julie Soyer|Julie Soyer]] and [[Jessica Houara]]. [[Camille Abily]], [[Sonia Bompastor]] and [[Zohra Ayachi]] also joined the club.{{cite news | title = Le nouveau visage du PSG | url = http://www.fff.fr/champ/femininesD1/actualite/390321.shtml | work = [[French Football Federation|FFF]] | date = 9 August 2009 | accessdate = 22 October 2009}} Paris Saint-Germain finished third in the [[2009â10 Division 1 FÃ©minine|league]] during the [[2009â10 Paris Saint-Germain F.C. (Ladies) season|2009â10]] season, the highest place in the club's history.{{cite news | title = Une belle saison pour les fÃ©minines | url = http://www.psg.fr/fr/Article/003001/Article/49314/Une-belle-saison-pour-les-feminines | work = PSG.fr | date = 14 June 2010 | accessdate = 2 September 2010}} The capital club captured the [[2009â10 Challenge de France|Coupe de France FÃ©minine]] by defeating [[Montpellier HSC (Ladies)|Montpellier]] 5â0 in the [[2010 Challenge de France Final|Final]] at the [[Stade Robert Bobin]]. The scoreline is the largest gap in the cup's young history. The title is the club's first major title and most prestigious honour to date. It is also the first time in [[Football in France|French football]] history that both the male and female sections of a club occupy both the country's national cups. The male section of Paris Saint-Germain claimed the [[2009â10 Coupe de France|French Cup]]. Camillo Vaz stayed as manager while Christophe Dedouche replaced Karine Noilhan as assistant coach for the [[2010â11 Paris Saint-Germain F.C. (Ladies) season|2010â11]] season. The face of the team changed slightly as Ingrid Boyeldieu, Ãmilie L'Huillier and StÃ©phanie Hoffele left Paris.{{cite news | title = Les FÃ©minines Ã  lâheure de la rentrÃ©e | url = http://www.psg.fr/fr/Article/003001/Article/50125/Les-Feminines-a-l-heure-de-la-rentree | work = PSG.fr | date = 1 September 2010 | accessdate = 2 September 2010}} Former Lyon striker [[KÃ¡tia]], however, joined as PSG's star signing and formed a lethal partnership along Ãlise Bussaglia.{{cite news | title = Katia signe au PSG | url = http://www.psg.fr/fr/Article/003001/Article/50104/D1-Fem-Katia-signe-au-PSG | work = PSG.fr | date = 31 August 2010 | accessdate = 2 September 2010}} The duo played an important role in PSG's qualification to the [[UEFA Women's Champions League]] for the first time in their history, crowned with a decisive victory over second-placed Montpellier in the final match of the season.{{cite news | title = Les filles du PSG en Champions League ! | url = http://www.psg.fr/fr/Article/003001/Article/53957/Les-filles-du-PSG-en-Champions-League | work = PSG.fr | date = 29 May 2011 | accessdate = 3 June 2011}} ==Honours== {{seealso|Paris Saint-Germain F.C. honours}} {| cellpadding="3" style="font-size:95%; background:#022662;" align=center | '''Friendly Tournaments''' | width="20%" style="color:red; background:#022662;" align=center | '''Reserves & Academy''' |- |valign="top"| |valign="top"| * '''[[:fr:Ligue de Paris Ãle-de-France de football|DH Ãle-de-France FÃ©minine]] (1) :''' [http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/accueil.php?id=246 2011] |} ==List of seasons== {{col-begin}} {{col-4}} *'''P''' = Position *'''Pld''' = Played *'''W''' = Won *'''D''' = Drawn *'''L''' = Lost *'''GF''' = Goals for *'''GA''' = Goals against *'''GD''' = Goal difference *'''Pts''' = Points {{col-4}} *'''W''' = Winner *'''RU''' = Runners-up *'''F''' = Final *'''SF''' = Semi-finals *'''QF''' = Quarter-finals *'''R1''' = Round 1 *'''R16''' = Round of 16 *'''R2''' = Round 2 *'''R32''' = Round of 32 *'''R3''' = Round 3 *'''R64''' = Round of 64 *'''2GS''' = Second Group Stage *'''GS''' = Group Stage {{col-4}} *'''D1''' = [[Division 1 FÃ©minine]] *'''D2''' = [[:fr:Championnat de France de football fÃ©minin D2|Division 2 FÃ©minine]] *'''CFF''' = [[Coupe de France FÃ©minine]] *Divisions in '''bold''' indicate a change in division. {{col-end}}

(Ladies) season|2010â11]] |[[2010â11 Division 1 FÃ©minine|D1]] |bgcolor=silver|2nd |22 |17 |1 |4 |43 |16 | +27 |74 |[[2010â11 Challenge de France|R32]] | | |align=left|{{flagicon|BRA}} [[KÃ¡tia]] |12 |} |- |} ==Stadia== {{Main|Camp des Loges}} The [[Camp des Loges]] is the training center and club headquarters of Paris Saint-Germain. Following the foundation of Paris Saint-Germain in 1974, the Camp des Loges began operating as a training center for the club. The PSG training center officially opened on 4 November 1975 with Pedro Alonso being installed as the club's first director. On 15 March 2006, in order to modernize the center, Paris Saint-Germain announced that the club would temporarily vacate the Camp des Loges in order for the facilities to be renovated. The renovations officially started in January 2008 and were completed on 4 October 2008. The entire process cost â¬5m. The new Camp des Loges, located 400 meters from the old, was inaugurated on 4 November 2008. The center hosts training sessions for the senior team and serves as the home facility for the club's [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C. Reserves and Academy|Reserves and Academy]] sides (both male and female), which both play their home matches at the Stade Georges LefÃ¨vre. ==Board and staff== {{fb oi header}} {{Fb oi information |bg= |id=Manager |i=Camillo Vaz}} {{Fb oi information |bg=y |id=Assistant Coach |i=Christophe Dedouche}} {{Fb oi information |bg= |id=Physical Trainer |i=Pascal Hilbert}} {{Fb oi information |bg=y |id=Head Doctor |i=StÃ©phane Cascua}} {{Fb oi information |bg= |id=Physiotherapists |i=CÃ©dric Dupuis, GwenaÃ«lle PelÃ©}} {{Fb oi footer |s=[http://www.psg.fr/fr/Feminines/409001/Presentation-feminines PSG.fr] |date=October 2011}} [[Image:P1070571 Entrainement PSG Stade Georges Lefevre.JPG|right|thumb|140px|Stade Georges LefÃ¨vre]] {{fb oi header}} {{Fb oi information |bg= |id=General Delegate |i=Pierre NoguÃ¨s}} {{Fb oi information |bg=y |id=Administrative Assistant |i=[[BÃ©rangÃ¨re Sapowicz]]}} {{Fb oi information |bg= |id=Director of Football |i=Sophie Perrichon}} {{Fb oi information |bg=y |id=Academy Director |i=Bertrand Reuzeau}} {{fb oi information |bg= |id={{Fb oi ground}} |i={{Fb oi ground|g=Stade Georges LefÃ¨vre|c=3,500|d=-}} }} {{Fb oi footer |s=[http://www.psg.fr/fr/Feminines/409001/Presentation-feminines PSG.fr] |date=October 2011}} ==Current squad== French teams are limited to three players without [[European Union|EU]] citizenship. The squad list includes only the principal nationality of each player; several non-European players on the squad have dual citizenship with an EU country. Also, players from the [[ACP countries]]âcountries in Africa, the [[Caribbean]], and the [[Oceania|Pacific]] that are signatories to the [[Cotonou Agreement]]âare not counted against non-EU quotas due to the [[Kolpak ruling]]. :''{{As of|2011|10|18}}.''{{cite news | title = Effectifs et rÃ©sultats (fÃ©minines) | url = http://www.psg.fr/fr/Association/4010001/Effectifs-et-resultats-feminines | work = PSG.fr | accessdate = 16 October 2010}}{{cite news | title = PSG - Championnat de France de D1 2011-2012 | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/equipe.php?equipe=9&id=248 | work = Footofeminin.fr | accessdate = 17 October 2011}}{{cite news | title = UEFA Women's Champions League - PSG | url = player|no=â|name=SolÃ¨ne Barbance|nat=France|pos=MF}} {{Fs player|no=â|name=[[Ella Masar]]|nat=USA|pos=FW}} {{Fs player|no=â|name=[[Allie Long]]|nat=USA|pos=FW}} {{Fs end}} ==Reserves and academy== {{Main|Paris Saint-Germain F.C. Reserves and Academy}} [[File:RÃ©serve du PSG 2007-2008.jpg|190px|right|thumb|PSG's reserve team in May 2008.]] The [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C. Reserves and Academy]] are the reserve team and academy of Paris Saint-Germain. The [[Camp des Loges]] serves as the home facility for the club's Reserves and Academy sides (both male and female), which play their home matches at the Stade Georges LefÃ¨vre. It is located in the [[Communes of France|commune]] of [[Saint-Germain-en-Laye]], located in the western suburbs of [[Paris]]. The facility is known for its high-level training and several prominent players have passed through the youth training center. Notable graduates include [[Nicolas Anelka]], [[Luis FernÃ¡ndez]], [[Mamadou Sakho]], [[BÃ©rangÃ¨re Sapowicz]] and [[:fr:AurÃ©lie Conforti|AurÃ©lie Conforti]]. Pedro Alonso was the first director of the center. Bertrand Reuzeau is the current director.{{cite news | title = PrÃ©sentation (centre de formation) | url = http://www.psg.fr/fr/Formation/400001/Presentation-formation | work = PSG.fr | accessdate = 18 October 2011}} PSG also has a pre-training center, which houses players aged 15 and under, located in [[Verneuil-sur-Seine]].{{cite news | title = PrÃ©sentation (prÃ©formation) | url = http://www.psg.fr/fr/Preformation/405001/Presentation-pre-formation | work = PSG.fr | accessdate = 18 October 2011}} The Camp des Loges is recognised by the [[French Football Federation|FFF]] as one of the best formation and pre-formation centers in [[France]], being classified as Class 1 and Class A in recent seasons.{{cite news | title = La prÃ©fo labellisÃ©e Â« Elite Â» | url = http://www.psg.fr/fr/News/101001/Fil-info/43979/La-prefo-labellisee-Elite | work = PSG.fr | date = 19 January 2009 | accessdate = 7 September 2010}} The [[Ligue de Football Professionnel|LFP]] announced the classification of training centers for the [[2010â11 Paris Saint-Germain F.C. season|2010â11]] season. PSG appeared in the top 10, being ranked 9th largely thanks to their double coronation as U-19 and U-17 French champions.{{cite news | title = Formation : le PSG dans le top 10 | url = http://www.paristeam.fr/club/formation-le-psg-dans-le-top-10-39370.html | work = ParisTeam | date = 23 July 2011 | accessdate = 24 July 2011}} PSG Reserves and Academy are one of the most prestigious in French football having won three [[:fr:Ligue de Paris Ãle-de-France de football|Coupe de Paris]], three Championnat National U-19, two Challenge du Meilleur Club de Jeunes, one [[:fr:Ligue de Paris Ãle-de-France de football|Championnat DH Paris]], one [[Coupe Gambardella]], one Championnat National U-17, one Championnat de France Cadets, one [[:fr:Carisport|Tournoi Carisport]] and one [[:fr:Ligue de Paris Ãle-de-France de football|DH Ãle-de-France FÃ©minine]]. ==References==
